content.body: Hi! can someone help merge this editorial typo fix: https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/9388 ?
Jake Archibald: note that `className` is already defined on `Element` as I pointed out earlier; I guess SVG overrides it, though you could probably use the other one if you really wanted to
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: note that className is already defined on Element as I pointed out earlier; I guess SVG overrides it, though you could probably use the other one if you really wanted to

content.body: annevk: when did you previously point that out? (Or do you mean `classList`?)
content.formatted_body: annevk: when did you previously point that out? (Or do you mean `classList`?)

content.body: Jake Archibald: I pointed out in the issue that it's defined in DOM so the request should maybe be tracked there
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: I pointed out in the issue that it's defined in DOM so the request should maybe be tracked there

content.body: Jake Archibald: don't blame you for missing it though, there's a lot of noise :-)
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: don't blame you for missing it though, there's a lot of noise :-)

content.body: annevk: ahh I did see that, but I didn't join the dots to "it's on `Element`"
content.formatted_body: annevk: ahh I did see that, but I didn't join the dots to "it's on `Element`"

content.body: But yeah, that makes sense
annevk: happy to move it to DOM, but I figured it'd be better to wait until there's general "let's do it for className and htmlFor" agreement, then split it into two issues
content.formatted_body: annevk: happy to move it to DOM, but I figured it'd be better to wait until there's general "let's do it for className and htmlFor" agreement, then split it into two issues

content.body: Ms2ger: how does the Wasm CG render proposals relative to the main spec? Like https://github.com/WebAssembly/gc/issues/376 makes a bunch of changes to the main spec and then I guess the main spec is occasionally merged back in or some such? But is the result rendered somewhere?
content.formatted_body: Ms2ger: how does the Wasm CG render proposals relative to the main spec? Like https://github.com/WebAssembly/gc/issues/376 makes a bunch of changes to the main spec and then I guess the main spec is occasionally merged back in or some such? But is the result rendered somewhere?

content.body: annevk: yeah, proposals are done in a fork of the main spec repo, which is merged into it occasionally. The result is rendered if someone managed to get the CI working
content.formatted_body: annevk: yeah, proposals are done in a fork of the main spec repo, which is merged into it occasionally. The result is rendered if someone managed to get the CI working

content.body: Example: https://webassembly.github.io/content-security-policy/js-api/#host-ensure-can-compile-wasm-bytes

> <@ms2ger:igalia.com> annevk: yeah, proposals are done in a fork of the main spec repo, which is merged into it occasionally. The result is rendered if someone managed to get the CI working

I've been asked to fix that CI. So I just need to make time to go in and do it. Next week at the earliest

content.body: Ah
To be honest, I haven't even looked at any of it yet
PLH told me long ago some stuff had stopped working there
But I as yet have zero idea of the specifics
Regardless, I'd be glad to help good whatever's busted
In particular whatever bits are the ones Eric had been taking care of
This isn't the thing Eric did, but since you offered, https://github.com/WebAssembly/js-types/issues/23 has been ignored for the last 2.5 years
Well that's a long time
I will go in and take a look
The reason I'm good at fixing strangely engineered builds that are broken is that I'm good at strangely engineering them to begin with myself, and breaking them

content.body:
* Is there any `EventSource` (or `EventSource`-like) web api for client/browser side communications?
I mean having event sources in client/browser side too, to consume those client/browser-side events when is needed mainly client/browser side (and maybe even server-side?)

I mean following the philosophy of `EventSource` and `EventTarget` for both client/browser and server side
To me it seems that `EventSource` and `EventTarget` comes from those old days that just server was the event source

content.body: annevk: in https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#fetch-groups, the last sentence, should it be "and keepalive", not "or keepalive" ?
content.formatted_body: annevk: in https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#fetch-groups, the last sentence, should it be "and keepalive", not "or keepalive" ?

content.body:
> <@smaug:mozilla.org> annevk: in https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#fetch-groups, the last sentence, should it be "and keepalive", not "or keepalive" ?

It looks correct with or
It allows for either condition to be true for the associated fetch record's controller to be terminated
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @smaug:mozilla.org
annevk: in https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#fetch-groups, the last sentence, should it be "and keepalive", not "or keepalive" ?
It looks correct with or
It allows for either condition to be true for the associated fetch record's controller to be terminated

content.body: but we don't want to terminate keepalives, no?
smaug: yeah, that looks wrong, file an issue?
content.formatted_body: smaug: yeah, that looks wrong, file an issue?

content.body: smaug: seems to have been wrong since I first drafted this concept: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/commit/744d8b3bbe3b59492cff5f0fdd49b8dd053c4571
content.formatted_body: smaug: seems to have been wrong since I first drafted this concept: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/commit/744d8b3bbe3b59492cff5f0fdd49b8dd053c4571

content.body: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues/1669

Hey folks, question on the Storage spec. I'm trying to get a callback for every site that accesses any form of non-cookie storage. Looking at the spec https://storage.spec.whatwg.org/, which is the best algorithm to monkey patch? I'm considering "obtain a storage bottle map / shelf / key", but I'm not clear on the flow. Are these called once the first time an origin accesses local or session storage, and never before then? Could the browser run them for a non-site reason?
